questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a persistent cough for the past 2 weeks. During this time, he has also had occasional discomfort in his chest. Three weeks ago, he had a sore throat, headache, and a low-grade fever, which were treated with acetaminophen and rest. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 57 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. Current medications include enalapril and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37.0째C (98.6째F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) allows for rapid assessment of valvular function, diameter of the aortic root, and detection of aortic dissection at the bedside. TTE is indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients with suspected TAA, but it is not the preferred imaging study in hemodynamically stable patients with mediastinal widening suggestive of TAA. Compared to alternative imaging modalities, TTE has lower sensitivity in diagnosing aortic pathologies.

B) CORRECT:

A CT angiography (CTA) of the chest is the preferred imaging modality for investigating mediastinal abnormalities detected on chest x-ray (e.g., mediastinal widening or a mediastinal mass) as it is accurate, rapid, and non-invasive. This patient's x-ray findings are strongly suggestive of a TAA, which can manifest with chest discomfort and cough due to compression of the tracheobronchial tree (although most TAAs are asymptomatic, and this patient's cough may be a sequela of his recent upper respiratory tract infection). However, a chest x-ray cannot accurately determine the underlying cause of mediastinal widening. CTA is the best confirmatory test for TAAs, delineates the size and length of the TAA, and detects complications (e.g., thrombus formation, free/contained TAA rupture), thereby providing valuable information for planning management. MR angiography is a reasonable alternative to CTA in hemodynamically stable patients who should avoid ionizing radiation.

C) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is an appropriate option if the cause of the widened mediastinum on a chest x-ray is aortic unfolding, the most common cause of this finding in older adults. However, aortic unfolding appears as an opened-up aortic arch on chest x-ray; it does not cause a tracheal shift. This patient has x-ray findings that are highly consistent with a TAA, which should be further investigated and confirmed or ruled out.

D) INCORRECT:

Emergency surgical repair is indicated for a ruptured/leaking TAA or aortic dissection, both of which can appear as a widened mediastinum on chest x-ray. However, both conditions cause severe thoracic pain (often indistinguishable from an acute myocardial infarction) and hemodynamic instability (tachycardia, hypotension, sometimes hypertension) is typically present. Emergency surgical repair is not an appropriate management option for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Approximately 20% of TAAs are hereditary, occurring either alone or as part of a syndrome (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Turner syndrome). Genetic testing should be considered if there is concern for a heredity etiology of the TAA, e.g., occurrence at a young age or family history or clinical features associated with any of these syndromes. However, in this 62-year-old patient who does not have signs or symptoms of hereditary TAA, genetic testing would not be indicated. Moreover, a confirmatory test to definitively diagnose TAA is warranted.

F) INCORRECT:

A pathology of any of the structures in the mediastinum can appear as mediastinal widening on chest x-ray. Some examples include enlarged hilar lymph nodes (e.g., due to pneumonia, tuberculosis, Hodgkin lymphoma), achalasia, cardiomegaly, thoracic aortic aneurysm/dissection, or tumors (e.g., teratoma, thymoma, extragonadal germ cell tumor). However, not all of these conditions require confirmation on biopsy, and biopsy of cardiovascular structures would be disastrous. Therefore, biopsy is not the next best step after detecting mediastinal widening on chest x-ray.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a female patient with lymphoma

Multiple masses abut the mediastinum in the central thorax. Their lateral margins are circumscribed, but their medial margins are not visible. This appearance is common for masses arising from the mediastinum. There is also mass effect on the trachea, deviating it to the left of the midline.

The right lateral costophrenic angle is slightly blunted, which may indicate the presence of a pleural effusion. Subtle opacification of the lower hemithoraces reflects overlying soft tissue and likely also atelectasis.

G) INCORRECT:

A barium esophagram is used in the diagnosis of esophageal disorders, including esophageal diverticula (e.g., Zenker diverticulum). Esophageal diverticula can cause chest discomfort and, in the case of regurgitation of food, cough. However, the absence of dysphagia, halitosis, and regurgitation of undigested food makes this diagnosis unlikely. The mediastinal widening in this patient is not due to an esophageal diverticulum.
questions.hint: This patient's chest x-ray shows bulging of the aorta (aortic knob or prominent shadow of the aortic arch) and a widened mediastinum. These findings are suggestive of a thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA).

questions.text: A previously healthy 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of upper back pain, dyspnea, and a sensation of pressure in his chest. He has had no palpitations, fevers, or chills. He emigrated from Ecuador when he was 5 years old. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He takes no medications. He is 194 cm (6 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 70.3 kg (155 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.2째C (99.0째F), pulse is 73/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 152/86 mm Hg in the right arm and 130/72 mm Hg in the left arm. Pulmonary examination shows faint inspiratory wheezing bilaterally. A CT scan of the chest with contrast is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Congenital narrowing of the aortic arch

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infection with Trypanosoma cruzi causes Chagas disease. Chronic Chagas disease manifests with dilated cardiomyopathy, but ascending aortic aneurysm would not be expected. Although this patient has immigrated to the United States from Ecuador, where T. cruzi is endemic, his CT imaging findings do not show dilated cardiomyopathy.

B) CORRECT:

Cystic medial necrosis of the aorta can lead to the development of an ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA), which may manifest with back pain and chest pressure. Different conditions can be associated with the occurrence of TAAs of the ascending aorta. A patient presenting with signs of a TAA and a tall height (194 cm) may have Marfan syndrome. Other conditions associated with TAA include Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, hypertension, the occurrence of a congenital bicuspid aortic valve, and cardiovascular syphilis causing aortitis.
Image Description:

Ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm: the most common type; can arise from the aortic valve to the brachiocephalic trunk
Aortic arch aneurysm: involves the brachiocephalic vessels
Descending thoracic aortic aneurysm: arises distal to the left subclavian artery

C) INCORRECT:

Large-vessel vasculitides such as Takayasu arteritis can affect the aortic arch and proximal great vessels, which can lead to discordant blood pressure readings between the upper limbs (due to aortic arch narrowing). Takayasu arteritis can, occasionally, lead to aneurysmal dilation of the ascending aorta with aortic regurgitation and dysphagia. However, this condition is usually associated with other features, such as decreased bilateral brachial and radial pulses, syncope, cutaneous nodules, fever, and/or night sweats. Moreover, Takayasu arteritis typically occurs in Asian women.

D) INCORRECT:

Atherosclerotic plaque formation is considered the most important pathophysiological mechanism underlying aneurysms in the thoracic segment and the abdominal segment of the descending aorta. Aortic atherosclerosis arises most often in elderly patients with risk factors for atherosclerosis such as hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and smoking; it would be unlikely that such a young patient would have atherosclerotic vascular disease. Furthermore, atherosclerotic lesions appear as hyperdense signals in the wall of the aorta. However, this patient's CT scan does not show any signs of aortic atherosclerosis. Furthermore, a different condition is more likely to be the underlying condition responsible for an ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm.

E) INCORRECT:

Congenital narrowing of the aortic arch at the isthmus is called aortic coarctation. The classic manifestation of aortic coarctation is disparate blood pressure measurements in the upper and lower extremities; only in the rare instance that the coarctation is proximal to the origin of the left subclavian artery would aortic coarctation cause disparate blood pressure measurements in the arms. Furthermore, this condition would not be expected to cause significant dilation of the ascending aorta.
questions.hint: This axial CT shows an ascending aortic aneurysm.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of sharp, shooting pain in both legs. Twenty years ago, he had a painless ulcer on his penis that resolved without treatment. He has no history of serious illness. Examination shows small pupils that constrict with accommodation but do not react to light. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the distal lower extremities. Patellar reflexes are absent bilaterally. His gait is unsteady and broad-based. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Development of atrioventricular block can be caused by various etiologies (e.g., infection, cardiomyopathy, ischemia); the most common infectious causes include Lyme disease and infective endocarditis (IE). This patient's syphilis infection would not increase his risk of developing atrioventricular block.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve regurgitation is a potential complication of rheumatic fever (RF) or rheumatic heart disease (due to untreated RF). RF can also manifest with neurological sequelae (e.g., Sydenham chorea); however, paresthesia and pupillary involvement would not be expected. This patient's syphilis infection would not increase his risk of developing mitral valve regurgitation.

C) INCORRECT:

Penile squamous cell carcinoma is associated with infection from high-risk strains of human papillomavirus (i.e., HPV-16, HPV-18). Anogenital lesions caused by HPV are usually raised, cauliflower-like, and exophytic, rather than the painless ulcers reported by this patient. This patient's syphilis infection would not increase his risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Cerebral artery septic embolism is almost exclusively seen in left-sided infective endocarditis, especially with Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus bovis infection, and can lead to the development of mycotic aneurysm. This patient has evidence of syphilis infection, which is not known to cause embolization.

E) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory polyarthritis can occur in patients with disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI) or reactive arthritis, but not syphilis infection. While synovitis can develop in patients with syphilis, it is more typically seen in secondary syphilis, and would classically manifest within 10 weeks of primary infection; this patient's infection has been present for much longer.

F) CORRECT:

In addition to tabes dorsalis and Argyll Robertson pupil, patients with tertiary syphilis are at risk of developing thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA) from aortitis. Treponemal-mediated destruction of the vasa vasorum classically affects the ascending aorta and can also lead to aortic root dilatation and aortic regurgitation. These cardiovascular complications are late manifestations of syphilis, and typically only occur after 15 years of untreated infection.
questions.hint: This patient has evidence of tabes dorsalis (ataxia, lower extremity pain, impaired sensation in the lower extremities) and Argyll Robertson pupil (impaired pupillary constriction), suggesting tertiary syphilis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man from Chile comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of upper back pain and difficulty swallowing. He has had pain in his shoulder and knee joints over the past 10 years. He is 190 cm (6 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 70.3 kg (155 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. His blood pressure is 142/86 mm Hg in the right arm and 130/70 mg Hg in the left arm. Physical examination shows a depression in the sternum and a grade 3/6 diastolic murmur at the right upper sternal border. A CT scan of the chest with contrast is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infection with the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi causes Chagas disease, which is endemic to South America. This disease can cause dysphagia (due to achalasia) as well as aortic regurgitation (due to dilated cardiomyopathy), which are seen here. However, Chagas disease would not cause pectus excavatum, discordant blood pressure readings, or dilation of the aorta.

B) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune valve damage is the cause of rheumatic heart disease (RHD), which, in the US, is most commonly seen in the immigrant population. RHD can cause a diastolic murmur (due to mitral stenosis), and, rarely, difficulty swallowing (dysphagia megalatriensis due to left atrial enlargement). Rheumatic fever, which is the pathologic precursor to RHD, would also cause pain in large joints such as the knee. However, the joint pain would subside after the acute episode of rheumatic fever, and the diastolic murmur of mitral stenosis would be heard best at the cardiac apex. This patient's murmur is caused by aortic regurgitation, which is not common in RHD. Most importantly, RHD would not cause dilation of the ascending aorta.

C) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous inflammation is seen in giant cell arteritis (GCA), which predisposes to the formation of ascending aortic aneurysms and can present with back and shoulder pain (due to concurrent polymyalgia rheumatica). However, aortic aneurysm usually occurs late in the course of GCA and the disease virtually never affects patients < 50 years.

Granulomatous inflammation is also seen in Takayasu arteritis, which can lead to chronic arthralgia and discordant blood pressure readings between the upper limbs (due to aortic arch narrowing). Takayasu arteritis can, occasionally, lead to aneurysmal dilation of the ascending aorta with aortic regurgitation and dysphagia, which is seen here. However, the condition typically occurs in Asian women and would usually be associated with other features, such as cutaneous nodules, fever, or night sweats.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic fibroblast proliferation is a pathologic process that occurs in patients with systemic sclerosis (SSc), which can cause dysphagia (due to esophageal dysmotility), chronic arthralgia, and vascular disease. Dysphagia due to SSc usually has a subacute or chronic onset. In addition, arthralgia caused by SSc typically affects the small joints of the hands and feet, and the vasculopathy associated with SSc manifests as Raynaud phenomenon, telangiectasia, or thromboembolic phenomena. Furthermore, SS would not cause pectus excavatum, discordant blood pressure readings, aortic regurgitation, or dilation of the ascending aorta.

E) INCORRECT:

Congenital narrowing of the aortic arch (aortic coarctation) can cause discordant blood pressure readings in the limbs. Additionally, a bicuspid aortic valve, which is commonly associated with aortic coarctation, can lead to aortic regurgitation (diastolic murmur at the right upper sternal border), which is seen here. However, in the case of aortic coarctation, the discordance is usually between the blood pressure measurements of the upper and lower extremities because the coarctation is typically located just distal to the left subclavian artery. Only in very rare instances would aortic coarctation cause disparate blood pressure measurements in the arms. Furthermore, this condition would not be expected to cause significant dilation of the ascending aorta.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's tall stature and pectus excavatum suggest Marfan syndrome. Individuals with Marfan syndrome have hypermobile joints, which predisposes them to chronic arthralgia as a result of recurrent sprains, bursitis, and/or early-onset osteoarthritis. Cystic medial degeneration, which occurs with aging and in connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, leads to the weakening of the aortic wall and aneurysmal dilation, which are seen here.

G) INCORRECT:

Weakening of the vessel wall due to atheroma formation (atherosclerosis) is the most common cause of an aortic aneurysm, and the marfanoid features in this patient (e.g., tall stature, pectus excavatum) might be due to homocystinuria, which is a risk factor for early-onset atherosclerosis. However, aneurysms due to atherosclerosis typically occur in the thoracic segment and the abdominal segment of the descending aorta. The ascending aortic aneurysm in this patient suggests a different pathologic process.
questions.hint: This axial CT shows an ascending aortic aneurysm, which is often associated with an aortic regurgitation murmur (diastolic murmur at the right upper sternal border) caused by dilation of the aortic valve annulus. Dissection of the weakened aneurysmal wall can cause an acute increase in the size of an aneurysm, manifesting with back pain, discordant blood pressure readings in the upper limbs, and difficulty swallowing (dysphagia aortica due to esophageal compression).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with hypertension is found to have a systolic ejection murmur. A transthoracic echocardiogram reveals a bicuspid aortic valve and a dilated ascending aorta.
A thoracic CT scan shows that the ascending aorta is 5.6 cm in diameter (reference, <3.5 cm).
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Annual monitoring with CT of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

When surgical repair is not yet indicated, annual imaging of the thoracic aorta (with e.g., transesophageal echocardiography) is recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

When surgical repair is not yet indicated, annual imaging of the thoracic aorta (with e.g., CT) is recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Beta-blocker therapy is used to slow the progression of aortic aneurysm dilation, but continued observation on beta-blocker therapy is not appropriate once surgical repair is indicated.

D) CORRECT:

Thoracic aortic aneurysms are usually asymptomatic until an acute, often catastrophic complication occurs (e.g., a dissection or rupture). In most patients, an ascending aortic aneurysm should be repaired surgically when it exceeds 5.5 cm in diameter or enlarges more than 0.5 cm per year. However, it should be repaired earlier (at 4.0 to 5.0 cm in diameter, depending on the condition) in patients with genetically mediated causes of aortic aneurysm (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Turner syndrome) because dissection or rupture may occur in these individuals with minimal aortic dilatation.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management approach for a patient with a bicuspid aortic valve who has an ascending aortic aneurysm > 5.5 cm in diameter is surgical repair of the aneurysm.

E) INCORRECT:

Endovascular repair for thoracic aortic aneurysms is not routinely recommended unless the patient is at prohibitive surgical risk.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old current smoker with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a BMI of 31 presents for follow-up of an asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm. He currently takes a beta-blocker and a statin. His blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg, his heart rate is 60 beats per minute, and his LDL cholesterol level is 68 mg/dL (reference range, <130).
Recent CT of the chest reveals that the aneurysms diameter has increased from 4.8 cm one year ago to 5.0 cm now.
Echocardiography reveals calcific aortic stenosis, with an aortic valve area of 1.2 cm2 and a mean gradient of 27 mm Hg (findings indicative of moderate aortic stenosis). The patient has no history of angina, syncope, near-syncope, or congestive heart failure.
Which one of the following interventions is the most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Aortic valve replacement and aortic aneurysm repair

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical intervention for ascending thoracic aortic aneurysms is indicated when the aneurysms diameter is > 5.5 cm or has expanded by > 0.5 cm per year.

B) INCORRECT:

If heart rate is well controlled, increasing the beta-blocker dose is unnecessary. In the patient with an aortic aneurysm, the therapeutic goal is to reduce blood pressure with beta-blockers, an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor, and/or an angiotensin-receptor blocker to the lowest point that the patient can tolerate without adverse effects.

C) CORRECT:

The most effective management strategies for patients with aortic aneurysm who do not require surgery are smoking cessation and blood-pressure control. The rate of expansion of thoracic aortic aneurysms among smokers is twice that in nonsmokers.

The size of the aneurysm should be monitored yearly, preferably by CT or MRI.

Key learning point: The most effective management strategies for patients with aortic aneurysm who do not require surgery are blood-pressure control and smoking cessation.

D) INCORRECT:

If blood pressure is well controlled, initiating an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor is unnecessary.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical intervention for ascending thoracic aortic aneurysms is indicated when the aneurysms diameter is > 5.5 cm or has expanded by > 0.5 cm per year. Aneurysms > 4.5 cm may be considered for correction in a patient who is undergoing cardiac surgery for another reason; however, this patient has no indication for cardiac surgery (moderate aortic stenosis is not a surgical indication).

In addition to tabes dorsalis and Argyll Robertson pupil, patients with tertiary syphilis are at risk of developing thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA) from aortitis. Treponemal-mediated destruction of the vasa vasorum classically affects the ascending aorta and can also lead to aortic root dilatation and aortic regurgitation. These cardiovascular complications are late manifestations of syphilis, and typically only occur after 15 years of untreated infection.

Key learning point: Tertiary syphilis can cause cardiovascular complications such as thoracic aortic aneurysm and aortic regurgitation due to syphilitic aortitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Development of atrioventricular block can be caused by various etiologies (e.g., infection, cardiomyopathy, ischemia); the most common infectious causes include Lyme disease and infective endocarditis (IE). This patient's syphilis infection would not increase his risk of developing atrioventricular block.
questions.hint: This patient has evidence of tabes dorsalis (ataxia, lower extremity pain, impaired sensation in the lower extremities) and Argyll Robertson pupil (impaired pupillary constriction), suggesting tertiary syphilis.

questions.text:
You are seeing a 75-year-old man who currently smokes and has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a BMI of 31. He is being followed for an asymptomatic ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm. He has no history of angina, syncope, near-syncope, or congestive heart failure. His medications include a beta-blocker and a statin. His blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg, heart rate is 60 beats per minute, and his low-density lipoprotein level (LDL) is 1.76 mmol/L.
Low-Density Lipoprotein (LDL) Analysis

High and intermediate

A recent chest CT shows the aneurysm diameter has increased from 4.8 cm one year ago to 5.0 cm now. Echocardiography shows moderate aortic stenosis. Which one of the following interventions is the most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Aortic valve replacement and aortic aneurysm repair.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical intervention for ascending thoracic aortic aneurysms is indicated when the aneurysms diameter is > 5.5 cm or has expanded by > 0.5 cm per year. Aneurysms > 4.5 cm may be considered for correction in a patient who is undergoing cardiac surgery for another reason; however, this patient has no indication for cardiac surgery (moderate aortic stenosis is not a surgical indication).

B) CORRECT:

The most effective management strategies for patients with aortic aneurysm who do not require surgery are smoking cessation and blood-pressure control. The rate of expansion of thoracic aortic aneurysms among smokers is twice that in nonsmokers.

The size of the aneurysm should be monitored yearly, preferably by CT or MRI.

Key learning point: The most effective management strategies for patients with aortic aneurysm who do not require surgery are blood-pressure control and smoking cessation.

C) INCORRECT:

If heart rate is well controlled, increasing the beta-blocker dose is unnecessary. In the patient with an aortic aneurysm, the therapeutic goal is to reduce blood pressure with beta-blockers, an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor, and/or an angiotensin-receptor blocker to the lowest point that the patient can tolerate without adverse effects.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical intervention for ascending thoracic aortic aneurysms is indicated when the aneurysms diameter is > 5.5 cm or has expanded by > 0.5 cm per year.

E) INCORRECT:

If blood pressure is well controlled, initiating an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor is unnecessary.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to your clinic because of a persistent cough for the past 2 weeks. He also reports occasional chest discomfort during this period. Three weeks ago, he experienced a sore throat, headache, and low-grade fever, which resolved with acetaminophen and rest. His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has a 40-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. His current medications are enalapril and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37.0째C, pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. A chest x-ray is provided. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Approximately 20% of TAAs are hereditary, occurring either alone or as part of a syndrome (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Turner syndrome). Genetic testing should be considered if there is concern for a heredity etiology of the TAA, e.g., occurrence at a young age or family history or clinical features associated with any of these syndromes. However, in this 62-year-old patient who does not have signs or symptoms of hereditary TAA, genetic testing would not be indicated. Moreover, a confirmatory test to definitively diagnose TAA is warranted.

B) INCORRECT:

A transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) allows for rapid assessment of valvular function, diameter of the aortic root, and detection of aortic dissection at the bedside. TTE is indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients with suspected TAA, but it is not the preferred imaging study in hemodynamically stable patients with mediastinal widening suggestive of TAA. Compared to alternative imaging modalities, TTE has lower sensitivity in diagnosing aortic pathologies.

C) INCORRECT:

Emergency surgical repair is indicated for a ruptured/leaking TAA or aortic dissection, both of which can appear as a widened mediastinum on chest x-ray. However, both conditions cause severe thoracic pain (often indistinguishable from an acute myocardial infarction) and hemodynamic instability (tachycardia, hypotension, sometimes hypertension) is typically present. Emergency surgical repair is not an appropriate management option for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is an appropriate option if the cause of the widened mediastinum on a chest x-ray is aortic unfolding, the most common cause of this finding in older adults. However, aortic unfolding appears as an opened-up aortic arch on chest x-ray; it does not cause a tracheal shift. This patient has x-ray findings that are highly consistent with a TAA, which should be further investigated and confirmed or ruled out.

E) CORRECT:

A CT angiography (CTA) of the chest is the preferred imaging modality for investigating mediastinal abnormalities detected on chest x-ray (e.g., mediastinal widening or a mediastinal mass) as it is accurate, rapid, and non-invasive. This patient's x-ray findings are strongly suggestive of a TAA, which can manifest with chest discomfort and cough due to compression of the tracheobronchial tree (although most TAAs are asymptomatic, and this patient's cough may be a sequela of his recent upper respiratory tract infection). However, a chest x-ray cannot accurately determine the underlying cause of mediastinal widening. CTA is the best confirmatory test for TAAs, delineates the size and length of the TAA, and detects complications (e.g., thrombus formation, free/contained TAA rupture), thereby providing valuable information for planning management. MR angiography is a reasonable alternative to CTA in hemodynamically stable patients who should avoid ionizing radiation.

Key learning point: CT angiography is the preferred confirmatory test for thoracic aortic aneurysm in stable patients with mediastinal widening seen on chest x-ray.
questions.hint: This patient's chest x-ray shows bulging of the aorta (aortic knob or prominent shadow of the aortic arch) and a widened mediastinum. These findings are suggestive of a thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA).

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a 40-pack-year smoking history and poorly controlled hypertension presents with a 4-week history of progressive dysphagia to solids and intermittent hoarseness. He reports no chest pain but describes a vague sense of chest fullness. Physical examination shows subtle jugular venous distention. Vital signs are BP, 165/95; P, 88; R, 18; T, 37.0째C (98.6째F). Chest x-ray is shown. What is the most appropriate diagnostic modality to perform next?

choices.text: MRI of the chest without contrast
CT angiography of the chest with IV contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI is an alternative to the preferred confirmatory diagnostic modality, but it is less readily available and takes longer to perform.

B) INCORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography is primarily used for rapid assessment in hemodynamically unstable patients or to evaluate for cardiac complications. This stable patient with classic compression symptoms requires definitive cross-sectional imaging to evaluate the aneurysm.

C) INCORRECT:

Esophageal barium swallow (esophagram) is a contrast-enhanced imaging study primarily used to evaluate dysphagia, esophageal motility disorders, and structural abnormalities of the esophagus. While this patient's dysphagia might initially suggest an esophageal etiology, the combination of hoarseness, chest fullness, and widened mediastinum indicates extrinsic compression from a thoracic aortic aneurysm.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- CT angiography of the chest with IV contrast is the best confirmatory test for thoracic aortic aneurysm and the most appropriate immediate step. This patient's constellation of symptoms (dysphagia, hoarseness, chest fullness) combined with physical findings (venous distention) and chest x-ray abnormalities strongly suggest mediastinal compression from a thoracic aortic aneurysm. Definitive imaging is essential to confirm the diagnosis, assess aneurysm size and location, and guide further management decisions.

E) INCORRECT:

Catheter angiography may mask the actual diameter of the aneurysm, and thrombus-filled discrete aneurysms might be missed. Noninvasive imaging techniques have largely replaced catheter angiography as first-line diagnostic tests for thoracic aortic aneurysms.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with acute onset severe chest pain and dizziness. He reports a history of thoracic and upper back pain for several months. Vital signs are BP, 95/60; P, 115; R, 22. He is alert and oriented but appears uncomfortable. Chest examination shows diminished breath sounds at the left base. POCUS shows pericardial effusion. A type and screen is obtained and IV fluids are started. Based on this patient's clinical presentation, which is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT angiography of chest, abdomen, and pelvis with IV contrast
MR angiography chest with and without IV contrast
Transthoracic echocardiography to evaluate aortic root diameter

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT angiography of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis with IV contrast is the appropriate confirmatory test for hemodynamically stable patients with suspected thoracic aortic aneurysm rupture. However, this patient's borderline hypotension and clinical presentation suggest potential hemodynamic instability requiring more immediate intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

MR angiography chest with and without IV contrast is an alternative to CT for confirmation of thoracic aortic aneurysm, but it is time-consuming and inappropriate for hemodynamically unstable patients with suspected thoracic aortic aneurysm rupture who require immediate intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography can provide rapid assessment in hemodynamically unstable patients and evaluate for cardiac pathology, but this patient requires immediate surgical consultation given the clinical presentation suggesting possible rupture.

D) CORRECT:

Correct This patient presents with concerning vital signs including hypotension that suggest potential hemodynamic instability from suspected thoracic aortic aneurysm rupture. Immediate resuscitation with blood products as soon as available and urgent cardiothoracic surgery consultation are essential, as patients may rapidly decompensate.

E) INCORRECT:

While chest radiograph may show supportive findings such as widened mediastinum, and electrocardiogram can help rule out myocardial infarction, these diagnostic studies delay critical interventions in a patient with suspected thoracic aortic aneurysm rupture and borderline hemodynamic stability.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a persistent, non-productive cough for the past month. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker with a 40-pack-year history. His blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg, and his physical examination is notable for a 2/6 systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border. A chest radiograph is obtained to evaluate his cough and reveals a prominent aortic knob and a widened superior mediastinum. The lung fields are clear. Which of the following is the most appropriate next diagnostic study to evaluate this finding?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance angiography of the chest
Computed tomography angiography of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conventional catheter-based aortography was once the gold standard for diagnosing aortic disease. However, it is an invasive procedure with risks such as bleeding, vessel injury, and atheroembolism. It has been largely supplanted by other imaging techniques, which provide more comprehensive information about the aortic wall, luminal thrombus, and surrounding structures. Aortography is now primarily used during endovascular interventions rather than for initial diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) provides high-resolution images of the thoracic aorta and is particularly useful for detecting aortic dissection, especially in unstable patients at the bedside. However, TEE is more invasive than other imaging modalities, requires sedation, and has a small blind spot in the distal ascending aorta and proximal arch. For a stable patient needing a comprehensive initial evaluation of a suspected aneurysm, other imaging modalities are generally preferred.

C) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is an excellent alternative for diagnosing and monitoring thoracic aortic aneurysms. However, it is generally not recommended as the first-line imaging modality and is often reserved for long-term surveillance.

D) INCORRECT:

A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is a useful non-invasive tool for evaluating the aortic root and the most proximal portion of the ascending aorta. It can also assess for aortic regurgitation, which can be associated with aortic root dilation. However, TTE provides inadequate visualization of the aortic arch and the descending thoracic aorta due to the overlying sternum and lungs, making it insufficient for fully evaluating the aneurysm suggested by the widened superior mediastinum and prominent aortic knob on the chest radiograph.

E) CORRECT:

Computed tomography angiography (CTA) is the preferred imaging modality for the initial diagnosis and evaluation of a suspected thoracic aortic aneurysm in a hemodynamically stable patient. It is rapid, widely available, and provides excellent spatial resolution to confirm the presence of an aneurysm, precisely measure its maximal diameter, and define its location and extent (e.g., ascending, arch, descending). This detailed anatomical information, including the aneurysm's relationship to major branch vessels like the subclavian or renal arteries, is crucial for determining the need for and type of intervention (open vs. endovascular repair). CTA can also identify complications such as intramural hematoma, penetrating atherosclerotic ulcer, or dissection.
questions.hint: The patient's chronic cough and chest radiograph findings of a widened mediastinum and prominent aortic knob, in the context of his atherosclerotic risk factors, are highly suggestive of a thoracic aortic aneurysm.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is evaluated before an elective inguinal hernia repair. He is asymptomatic. His past medical history is significant for hypertension controlled with amlodipine. His father died suddenly at age 50 from an aortic dissection. His blood pressure is 128/78 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. On cardiac examination, an early systolic ejection click is heard at the apex. A transthoracic echocardiogram confirms a bicuspid aortic valve with mild regurgitation and a dilated aortic root. A subsequent gated CT angiogram of the chest demonstrates an ascending aortic aneurysm measuring 5.6 cm in diameter. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Continue amlodipine and repeat imaging in one year
Initiate metoprolol and repeat imaging in 6 months
Schedule for aortic valve replacement only
Referral to a cardiothoracic surgeon for elective repair

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While blood pressure control is crucial, this represents inadequate management. Annual imaging is an appropriate interval for smaller, stable aneurysms, but this patient's condition requires definitive intervention rather than continued surveillance.

B) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers like metoprolol are a mainstay of medical therapy to reduce aortic wall stress in patients with thoracic aortic aneurysms undergoing surveillance. However, this patient's aneurysm diameter of 5.6 cm warrants a different management intervention. Medical management and surveillance alone are no longer the most appropriate primary strategy.

C) INCORRECT:

The patient's most life-threatening pathology is the 5.6 cm ascending aortic aneurysm, which carries a significant risk of dissection and rupture. The aortic valve only has mild regurgitation. Performing an isolated valve replacement would fail to address the aneurysm and would leave the patient at high risk for an aortic catastrophe.

D) CORRECT:

Current guidelines recommend elective surgical repair of an ascending aortic aneurysm when the diameter is 5.5 cm. This asymptomatic patient's aneurysm measures 5.6 cm, and he has a strong family history, clearly meeting the indication for surgical referral. The procedure typically involves replacement of the ascending aorta, often combined with aortic valve repair or replacement.

E) INCORRECT:

Urgent or emergent surgery is indicated for acute aortic dissection, aneurysm rupture, or in patients who are symptomatic (e.g., new chest, back, or abdominal pain). This patient is asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable.
questions.hint: This patients aortic aneurysm is associated with risk factors such as a bicuspid aortic valve and a positive family history.
